title: In Afghanistan, ‘Who Has the Guns Gets the Land’
content: A decades-long fight over land has been reinvigorated as Taliban leaders look to reward their fighters with property, even if that means evicting others.

more_info.byline: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Yaqoob Akbary and Jim Huylebroek
des_facet: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

title: Samba, Cachaça and Pickled Eggs: ‘Dirty Feet’ Bars Are ‘Essence of Rio’
content: A cross between a dive bar and a greasy spoon, Rio de Janeiro’s beloved (and proudly filthy) hole-in-the wall joints are some of the most democratic spaces in a deeply unequal city.

more_info.byline: By Jack Nicas and Dado Galdieri

title: Stabbed 20 Times by Her Husband, She Now Fights Laws Favoring Abusers
content: Shira Isakov, once a little-known Israeli working in advertising, has become a national force in the struggle to combat domestic violence and change the legal landscape on parental rights.

title: 6-Year-Old in International Custody Battle Returns to Italy From Israel
content: Eitan Biran, who lost his parents in a cable car crash in Italy this year, had been taken to Israel by his grandfather, who is under investigation for abduction.

more_info.byline: By Elisabetta Povoledo and Ronen Bergman

title: Iran Nuclear Talks Head for Collapse Unless Tehran Shifts, Europeans Say
content: In Vienna talks, the new hard-line Iranian government has staked out positions that are incompatible with the 2015 deal, European negotiators say.

des_facet: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

title: Lebanese Minister Who Criticized War in Yemen Resigns Under Saudi Pressure
content: Comments by the information minister, before he joined the government, prompted a diplomatic rift between Lebanon and powerful Gulf States. It was unclear if his resignation would end the crisis.

title: Taliban Decree an End to Forced Marriages in Afghanistan
content: The decree, attributed to the group’s religious leader, calls for more rights for women under Islamic law, but does not say whether women will regain easier access to education or jobs.

title: Philippine Court Allows Maria Ressa to Attend Nobel Peace Prize Ceremony
content: The decision came after days of growing international pressure on the government to allow the journalist to attend the ceremony in Norway.

title: A Slow-Motion Climate Disaster: The Spread of Barren Land
content: Brazil’s northeast, long a victim of droughts, is now effectively turning into a desert. The cause? Climate change and the landowners who are most affected.

more_info.byline: By Jack Nicas and Victor Moriyama

title: Prior Infection Is Little Defense Against Virus Variant, Scientists Say
content: Evidence from South Africa, where the Omicron variant already dominates, shows a high rate of reinfection of people who have already had the coronavirus.

more_info.byline: By Lynsey Chutel and Richard Pérez-Peña

title: Travelers to U.S. Count the Hours: Can They Get Their Tests Back in Time?
content: New travel restrictions announced on Thursday by the White House over fears of the spread of the Omicron variant have many worrying that their trips may not happen.

org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

title: Germany Shuts Unvaccinated People Out of Much of Public Life
content: Facing a huge coronavirus surge, Chancellor Angela Merkel, her successor, Olaf Scholz, and state governors agreed on tough new restrictions on people who have not been inoculated.

title: Migration Talking Points Surge in France, but Not Migration
content: With a presidential election looming, French presidential hopefuls are hardening their positions against immigration even as other countries compete for migrant workers.

des_facet: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

title: Switzerland backtracks on mandatory quarantines for some foreign visitors.
content: Reservations for the Christmas vacation season had plummeted over the Covid restrictions.

title: At Least One Dead as Volcano Erupts in Indonesia, Spewing Ash Cloud
content: Dozens more suffered burns as lava flowed from the eruption of Mount Semeru, on the island of Java.

more_info.byline: By Aina J. Khan and Muktita Suhartono

title: The detection of Omicron in the U.S. expands, as forecast, with at least 2 dozen cases across 12 states.
content: Most of the infected had traveled to southern Africa recently, but health officials are bracing for the inevitable community spread.

org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

title: Facing Economic Collapse, Afghanistan Is Gripped by Starvation
content: An estimated 22.8 million people — more than half the country’s population — are expected to face potentially life-threatening food insecurity this winter. Many are already on the brink of catastrophe.

org_facet: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations

title: Dr. Sherif R. Zaki, Acclaimed Disease Detective, Dies at 65
content: He helped identify numerous viruses, including Covid-19, as well as the bioterrorism attack that spread anthrax in 2001.

org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

title: Honeybees Survived for Weeks Under Volcano Ash After Canary Islands Eruption
content: For roughly 50 days, thousands of honeybees sealed themselves in their hives, away from deadly gas, and feasted on honey. “It is a very empowering story,” one entomologist said.

title: In France, a Right-Wing Polemicist Tries Channeling De Gaulle to Win Votes
content: Éric Zemmour has adopted imagery reminiscent of Charles de Gaulle, the wartime leader. But his call for reborn glory for France is sharply at odds with the realities of the country today.

title: Belgian Port City Grapples With a Flood of Cocaine
content: Antwerp has become the main port of entry into Europe for the drug, which is being blamed for a surge of violence that has prompted some Belgian officials to call for a war on drugs.

title: The Variant Hunters: Inside South Africa’s Effort to Stanch Dangerous Mutations
content: Scientists in a cutting-edge laboratory do part of the work. Local health workers on foot do the rest.

title: Parents of Michigan Shooting Suspect Arrested in Detroit, Police Say
content: The couple were charged after officials said their son carried out the shootings using a handgun his parents had bought for him.

more_info.byline: By Gerry Mullany, Eduardo Medina and Sophie Kasakove
org_facet: Oxford High School (Oxford Charter Township, Mich)

title: F.D.A. authorizes Eli Lilly antibody treatment for high-risk young children.
content: Doctors have a new option for the youngest patients who are vulnerable to the worst outcomes from Covid.

title: Congo Ousts Mining Leader in a Cloud of Corruption Claims
content: The country’s president removed Albert Yuma Mulimbi as chairman of the state mining firm. Cobalt in Congo is a crucial resource in the global clean energy revolution.

more_info.byline: By Eric Lipton and Dionne Searcey

title: Short-handed hospitals in upstate New York fill up as Covid cases surge.
Omicron Variant Spreading Twice as Quickly as Delta in South Africa
content: A new mathematical analysis strengthens concerns about the effects of the new variant on the pandemic’s course.

title: Republican legislators protest vaccination rule at New Jersey’s State House.
An Unexpected Display of Unity in a Normally Fractious Parliament
content: After bitterly opposing an earlier attempt to ban conversion therapy, the Conservatives whisked a new bill through the House of Commons.

title: A man in Italy tries to get a shot in a fake arm to qualify for a vaccination certificate.
content: The stratagem was the latest and perhaps most original episode of vaccine evasion in the struggle between Italy’s government and the country’s anti-vaccine faction.

title: Fauci and other top U.S. health officials project resolve in fighting the Omicron variant.
content: After the first case of an Omicron infection was detected in the U.S., the country saw the highest daily total of vaccine shots since May, though the reporting could be skewed by holiday reporting lags.

org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

title: Cognitive Rehab: One Patient’s Painstaking Path Through Long Covid Therapy
content: Samantha Lewis is relearning some basic aspects of her daily life after struggling with brain fog and other lingering symptoms for more than a year since being infected by the virus.

more_info.byline: By Pam Belluck and Alex Wroblewski

title: Botswana’s leader says foreign diplomats who traveled from Europe were among the first known Omicron cases.
content: Botswana and South Africa were the first countries to identify cases involving the Omicron variant, and an official in Botswana asserted that most of the initial 19 were “imported.”

title: ‘We Cannot Keep Quiet’: Pope Laments Indifference on Migrants
content: In a visit to Cyprus, Francis said it was his “responsibility to help open eyes” to migrants’ plight but acknowledged that the small island “can’t do everything” to accommodate so many people.

des_facet: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

title: A Christmas party in Norway becomes a possible Omicron-spreading event, and other international news.
content: All those infected were fully vaccinated and tested before entering a restaurant in central Oslo, where one traveler from South Africa carried the new variant.

more_info.byline: By Thomas Erdbrink, Henrik Pryser Libell, Natasha Frost and John Yoon

title: English Teenager Finds Bronze Age Ax Using a Metal Detector
content: On her third day out with a metal detector, Milly Hardwick, 13, found a hoard of items from more than 3,000 years ago. “We were just laughing our heads off,” she said.
